001package imagingbook.lib.tuples;
002
003/**
004 * An elementary "handle" mechanism to facilitate indirect (two-stage)
005 * references to objects.
006 * The main purpose is to allow true "calls by reference", as shown in 
007 * Example 1 below.
008 * The second application is de-referencing of a tuple's elements
009 * into named variables, as in Example 2.
010 * 
011 * @author WB
012 *
013 * @param <T> the element type of this handle
014 */
015public class Handle<T> {
016        
017        private T obj;
018                
019        public Handle(T obj) {
020                this.obj = obj;
021        }
022        
023        public T get() {
024                return this.obj;
025        }
026        
027        public void set(T obj) {
028                this.obj = obj;
029        }
030        
031        public static <T> Handle<T> of(T obj) {
032                return new Handle<T>(obj);
033        }
034        
035        // ---------------------------------------------
036        
037        private static void foo(Handle<Integer> h) {
038                h.set(33);
039        }
040
041        public static void main(String[] args) {
042                Handle<Integer> a1 = Handle.of(10);
043                Handle<Integer> a2 = Handle.<Integer>of(10);
044                
045                Handle<Double> b = new Handle<>(10.0);
046                Handle<String> s = Handle.of("prima!");
047                
048                System.out.println("orig a = " + a1.get());
049                
050                // Example 1: call by reference (foo modifies the contents of a)
051                foo(a1);
052                System.out.println("modified a = " + a1.get());
053                
054
055        }
056
057
058}
